HISTORY: 59-year-old male with end stage renal disease and on hemodialysis
through a right internal jugular vein (IJ) tunneled catheter which showed poor
flow in the last dialysis. Patient also had left arm arteriovenous graft
placed in August which does not show thrill or pulsation.
RADIOLOGISTS: The procedure was performed by Drs. [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) **] and [**Name5 (PTitle) 1579**] [**Doctor Last Name **]
d'Othee with Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **] [**Name (STitle) 7250**]
the entire procedure.
PROCEDURE AND FINDINGS: The risks
note_date: benefits were explained to the patient and

person_id: informed consent was obtained. The patient was placed supine on the
angiographic table and the right neck and the left arm were prepped and draped
in sterile fashion. 1% Lidocaine was injected around the dialysis catheter
exit site for local anesthesia.
Contrast angiograms through both lumens of the catheter demonstrated extensive
fibrin sheaths surrounding the catheter tip. Under fluoroscopic guidance
0.035 Amplatz wires were advanced through both lumens of the catheter
respectively with the tip in the inferior vena cava. The catheter was removed.
An 8 French [**Last Name (un) 534**]-Tip sheath was advanced over a wire with the tip in right
lower internal jugular vein. Venogram by injection through the sidearm of the
sheath again showed extensive filling defect in the right brachiocephalic vein
and upper portion of the superior vena cava (SVC)
sheath.
Fibrin sheath venoplasty was performed with a 8 mm x 4 cm balloon first
then a 14 mm x 4 cm balloon. Follow-up contrast venogram through the sheath
demonstrated the flow tract in the right brachiocephalic vein and SVC is
widely open
note_time: linear filling defects were still visualized but

person_id: deviated to the right side of the vein.
Subsequently a 14.5 French
note_time: 24 cm-long (19 cn from cuff to tip)

person_id: tunneled dialysis catheter was placed over the wire with the tip in the
proximal right atrium. The catheter was flushed and locked with heparin
solution. 0 Prolene stitches were used to secure the catheter to the skin.
(Over)
DIAL CHECK/REPO                                                 Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 9049**]
Reason: PATIENT NEEDS A NEW PERMACATH
note_date: CURRENT R IJ PERMACATH IS NOT

person_id: Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 85
FINAL REPORT
(Cont)
Examination of the left upper arm AV graft revealed no thrill or pulsation.
Using ultrasound guidance
note_date: the graft was accessed with a 21 gauge needle close

person_id: to the arterial anastomosis pointing to the venous outflow. An 0.018 wire was
advanced through the needle into the graft. The needle was exchanged for a
small introducer of the micropuncture set.
Fistulogram with injection of nonionic contrast was performed and demonstrated
occlusion at the venous anastomosis and absence of opacification of a good-
caliber venous outlow.
The graft itself is partially opacified and partially occupied with filling
defects suggestive of thrombosis.
There was also a large filling defect in the brachial artery just below the
arterial anastomosis
note_date: that seems to extend up to just above the bifurcation of

person_id: the brachial artery. The brachial artery distal to the anastomosis is still
patent but with faint opacification.
After discussion with the referring surgeon (Dr [**Last Name (STitle) 7847**])
stopped at this stage. The catheter sheath was removed and local hemostasis
was achieved by manual compression.
COMPLICATIONS: The patient tolerated the procedure well with no complications.
IMPRESSION:
1. Extensive fibrin sheath surrounding the distal portion of the right IJ
access dialysis catheter treated with fibrin sheath venoplasty and replacement
of the tunneled dialysis catheter.
2. Occlusion of the left arm arteriovenous graft and venous anastomosis and
partial obstruction of the brachial artery just downstream the arteriovenous
anastomosis.

AV FISTULOGRAM SCH                                              Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 13293**]
Reason: functioning AVF
Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 150
* 35476 PTA VENOUS                     35476 PTA VENOUS                    *
* -59 DISTINCT PROCEDURAL SERVICE      36010 INTRO CATH SVC/IVC            *
* -51 MULTI-PROCEDURE SAME DAY         75978 PTA VENOUS                    *
* 75978 PTA VENOUS                     -59 DISTINCT PROCEDURAL SERVICE     *
* 75790 ART VENEOUS SHUNT              -22 EXTRA CHARGE                    *
* CATH
* C1894 INT.SHTH NOT/GUID
UNDERLYING MEDICAL CONDITION:
63 year old man with h/o ESRD on HD with new SVC syndrome
L  AVF.
REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
functioning AVF
FINAL REPORT
HISTORY: 63 year old male with end stage renal disease on dialysis through
left arm brachiocephalic arteriovenous (AV) fistula
significant swelling of left face and both arms with left side being worse.
RADIOLOGISTS: Drs. [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) 603**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 470**] and [**Name5 (PTitle) 291**] [**Doctor Last Name 292**] d'Othee
radiologist Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 292**] [**Name (STitle) 293**] being present for the entire procedure. Dr.
[**Last Name (STitle) 212**] reviewed the exam.
PROCEDURE AND FINDINGS: The risks and benefits were explained to the patient
and consent was obtained. The patient was placed supine on the angiographic
table and the right arm was prepped and draped in sterile fashion. Local
anesthesia using 1% Lidocaine was applied to the puncture site. Under
sonographic guidance
note_date: the left cephalic vein near the arteriovenous fistula

person_id: was accessed using a 21 gauge needle and an 0.018 wire was placed into the
vein toward the venous side. The needle was exchanged for a micropuncture
sheath which was connected to the power injector.
AV fistulogram was performed along the course of the cephalic vein to the
level of the right atrium. The venograms demonstrated a focal stenosis in the
dilated cephalic vein at the level of the mid arm and also confirmed the
known
note_date: severe stenosis of the superior vena cava (SVC). There is a left

person_id: internal jugular dialysis catheter with its tip in the SVC. This might be
related to the development of the stenosis. No intrathoracic collateral is
seen; there is
note_time: collateral filling from the left mid-arm towards the

person_id: axilla and then left lateral thoracic wall caudally.
Pressure measurements were performed through a 5-French straight catheter.
They demonstrated mean pressures of 13 mmHg in the right atrium and 31 mmHg in
the left brachiocephalic vein (i.e.
A pressure cuff was insufflated over the upper arm and a venogram was
repeated. It revealed patency of the arteriovenous anastomosis and the
brachial artery proximally and distally to the anastomosis with no significant
stenosis.
(Over)
AV FISTULOGRAM SCH                                              Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 13293**]
Reason: functioning AVF
Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 150
FINAL REPORT
(Cont)
Thereafter
note_date: an 0.035 [**Doctor Last Name 471**] wire was placed through the sheath and advanced

person_id: under fluoroscopy until its tip was in the inferior vena cava. The
micropuncture sheath was exchanged for a 6 French sheath. The focal stenosis
in the cephalic vein was dilated using a 6 mm X 4 cm balloon. Resolution of
the narrowing was shown on a follow-up venogram.
The sheath was removed and a 18 mm X 4 cm balloon was placed over the wire
into the stenotic SVC and dilated repeatedly under fluoroscopy up to 5
atmospheres. Follow up venograms through the sidearm of the sheath showed
significant improvement of the diameter of the SVC. Repeat pressure
measurements through a 4 French multiside hole straight catheter showed
complete resolution of pressure gradient across the superior vena cava.
The catheter and sheath were then removed and local hemostasis was achieved by
manual compression. The patient tolerated the procedure well with no
complications.
MEDICATIONS: For conscious sedation
note_date: a total of 75 micrograms of Fentanyl was

person_id: given in small divided intravenous doses under continuous hemodynamic
monitoring. Total of 165 ml IV Optiray 320 dilated by half.
IMPRESSION:
1.  Major
note_date: symptomatic stenosis of the superior vena cava. Low-pressure

person_id: balloon venoplasty (18 mm) resulted in highly satisfactory immediate
angiographic and manometric results.
2.  Focal stenosis in the left cephalic vein at the mid-arm level. This was
dilated to 6 mm in diameter with no immediate complication.
CT ABDOMEN W/O CONTRAST; CT PELVIS W/O CONTRAST                 Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 10700**]
Reason: r/o bleed
Admitting Diagnosis: CONGESTIVE HEART FAILURE
UNDERLYING MEDICAL CONDITION:
68 year old man with CAD
note_text: COPD here in hospital for cath on

person_id: Monday now with acute Hct drop from 33 - 26 - 24 overnight.
REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
r/o bleed
CONTRAINDICATIONS for IV CONTRAST:
h/o diabetes
FINAL REPORT
HISTORY:  68 y/o man status post CABG and acute drop in hematocrit.
TECHNIQUE: Axial images of the abdomen and pelvis were obtained without IV
contrast.
COMPARISONS: Not available.
CT ABDOMEN W/O CONTRAST:  Lung bases demonstrate patchy opacity in the region
of the lingula. There is no pleural effusion. The liver appears unremarkable
without focal abnormality.  There are several small gallstones noted within
the gallbladder.  The pancreas
appear unremarkable.  There is a small punctate calcification noted within the
mid pole of the left kidney which could represent a small renal stone. There
is no evidence of hydronephrosis.  Visualized large and small bowel loops
appear unremarkable. There is no significant mesenteric or retroperitoneal
lymphadenopathy.  There is no free air or free fluid within the abdomen.
CT PELVIS W/O CONTRAST:  The prostate is slight enlarged. The urinary bladder
and rectum appear unremarkable.  There is no pelvic lymphadenopathy or pelvic
free fluid.
BONE WINDOWS demonstrate no evidence of suspicious lytic or blastic lesions.
IMPRESSION:
1) No evidence of retroperitoneal hemorrhage.
2) Cholelithiasis without evidence of cholecystitis.
3) Lingular infiltrate and pneumonia should be considered in the appropriate
clinical setting.
4) There is a small subcentimeter stone within the left kidney without
evidence of hydronephrosis.

1. Subdural hematoma. 89 y/o M with h/o afib

FINDINGS:  On diffusion-weighted images there is a small area of restricted
diffusion along the falx within the left occipitotemporal lobe.  It is also
bright on FLAIR-weighted images and may represent a subacute infarct. Clinical
correlation is recommended.  On gradient echo images there is a large area of
intraparenchymal hemorrhage within the right parietal lobe and left thalamus
which following administration of gadolinium reveals ring-enhancing lesions.
These are suspicious for hemorrhagic metastases given the patient's history.
Additional ring-enhancing lesions throughout the supra- and infratentorial
compartments are visualized.  There is a moderate amount of peritumoral edema
involving the right parietal lobe lesion in addition to a second right
parietal lesion along the falx high in the vertex.  The other areas of
metastases reveal a minimal amount of peritumoral edema.
Family at bedside.  Support withdrawn

BRIEF HOSPITAL COURSE:  The patient was admitted to the
Trauma SICU.  Nipride drip was started.  Blood pressure was
monitored with an arterial line.  Blood pressures initially
were well controlled in the 130s systolic.  We then placed a
ventricular drain.  The patient prior to the ventricular
drain received 1 mg of midazolam and 1 mg of Morphine.  The
patient tolerated the ventricular drain placement well.
After the ventricular drain was placed
neurologically unchanged.  The ICP at the time of ventricular
drain placement was approximately 8.  The patient remained
with stable vital signs until approximately one hour after
the drain was placed at which time his blood pressure
increased.  This increase was to the point
pressure was in the low 200 systolic.
Nipride was pressed up and blood pressure was controlled down
into the high 170s.  The patient then became apneic.  His
systolic pressure dropped dramatically.  He became
unresponsive.  Neurologic examination at that time revealed
pupils were blown bilaterally.  Patient was unresponsive.  He
had no corneal or gag reflex.  Patient's blood pressure then
continued to drop and he became asystolic.
Time of death was 3:55 a.m.  The patient's sister was
contacted.  She did not wish to undergo autopsy.  The medical
examiner was contacted and he did not wish to go ahead with
examination.

EXAMINATION:  MRI of the brain with and without gadolinium.
INDICATION:  [**Age over 90 **] year old woman with lung cancer and right intracranial bleed
and history of brain metastases.  Please evaluate for acute infarct.
TECHNIQUE:  Multiplanar T1 and T2-weighted images of the brain with gadolinium
according to standard departmental protocol.  No prior study for comparison.
FINDINGS:  On diffusion-weighted images there is a small area of restricted
diffusion along the falx within the left occipitotemporal lobe.  It is also
bright on FLAIR-weighted images and may represent a subacute infarct. Clinical
correlation is recommended.  On gradient echo images there is a large area of
intraparenchymal hemorrhage within the right parietal lobe and left thalamus
which following administration of gadolinium reveals ring-enhancing lesions.
These are suspicious for hemorrhagic metastases given the patient's history.
Additional ring-enhancing lesions throughout the supra- and infratentorial
compartments are visualized.  There is a moderate amount of peritumoral edema
involving the right parietal lobe lesion in addition to a second right
parietal lesion along the falx high in the vertex.  The other areas of
metastases reveal a minimal amount of peritumoral edema.

HISTORY: 59-year-old male with end stage renal disease and on hemodialysis
through a right internal jugular vein (IJ) tunneled catheter which showed poor

placed in August which does not show thrill or pulsation.

d'Othee with Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **] [**Name (STitle) 7250**]
the entire procedure.
PROCEDURE AND FINDINGS: The risks
note_date: benefits were explained to the patient and

person_id: informed consent was obtained. The patient was placed supine on the
angiographic table and the right neck and the left arm were prepped and draped
in sterile fashion. 1% Lidocaine was injected around the dialysis catheter
exit site for local anesthesia.
Contrast angiograms through both lumens of the catheter demonstrated extensive
fibrin sheaths surrounding the catheter tip. Under fluoroscopic guidance
0.035 Amplatz wires were advanced through both lumens of the catheter
respectively with the tip in the inferior vena cava. The catheter was removed.
An 8 French [**Last Name (un) 534**]-Tip sheath was advanced over a wire with the tip in right
lower internal jugular vein. Venogram by injection through the sidearm of the
sheath again showed extensive filling defect in the right brachiocephalic vein
and upper portion of the superior vena cava (SVC)
sheath.
Fibrin sheath venoplasty was performed with a 8 mm x 4 cm balloon first
then a 14 mm x 4 cm balloon. Follow-up contrast venogram through the sheath
demonstrated the flow tract in the right brachiocephalic vein and SVC is
widely open
note_time: linear filling defects were still visualized but

person_id: deviated to the right side of the vein.
Subsequently a 14.5 French
note_time: 24 cm-long (19 cn from cuff to tip)

person_id: tunneled dialysis catheter was placed over the wire with the tip in the
proximal right atrium. The catheter was flushed and locked with heparin
solution. 0 Prolene stitches were used to secure the catheter to the skin.
(Over)

Examination of the left upper arm AV graft revealed no thrill or pulsation.
Using ultrasound guidance
note_date: the graft was accessed with a 21 gauge needle close

person_id: to the arterial anastomosis pointing to the venous outflow. An 0.018 wire was
advanced through the needle into the graft. The needle was exchanged for a
small introducer of the micropuncture set.
Fistulogram with injection of nonionic contrast was performed and demonstrated
occlusion at the venous anastomosis and absence of opacification of a good-
caliber venous outlow.
The graft itself is partially opacified and partially occupied with filling
defects suggestive of thrombosis.
There was also a large filling defect in the brachial artery just below the
arterial anastomosis
note_date: that seems to extend up to just above the bifurcation of

person_id: the brachial artery. The brachial artery distal to the anastomosis is still
patent but with faint opacification.
After discussion with the referring surgeon (Dr [**Last Name (STitle) 7847**])
stopped at this stage. The catheter sheath was removed and local hemostasis
was achieved by manual compression.
COMPLICATIONS: The patient tolerated the procedure well with no complications.
IMPRESSION:
1. Extensive fibrin sheath surrounding the distal portion of the right IJ
access dialysis catheter treated with fibrin sheath venoplasty and replacement
of the tunneled dialysis catheter.
2. Occlusion of the left arm arteriovenous graft and venous anastomosis and
partial obstruction of the brachial artery just downstream the arteriovenous
anastomosis.

Reason: Evaluate for leptomeningeal enhancement.
Admitting Diagnosis: NON-HODGKIN'S LYMPHOMA;NEUTROPENIC;FEVER
Contrast: MAGNEVIST Amt: 15
UNDERLYING MEDICAL CONDITION:
55 year old man with enteropathy-associated T cell lymphoma.
REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
Evaluate for leptomeningeal enhancement.
FINAL REPORT
INDICATION:  This is a 55 year old man with history of sprue and a T-cell
lymphoma of the small bowel.  Assess for leptomeningeal enhancement.  Recent
bone marrow biopsy revealed findings suspicious for T-cell lymphoma throughout
the marrow.
TECHNIQUE: Sagittal T1
sagittal T1 weighted images post gadolinium contrast administration were
obtained.  There are no prior spine MRI's for comparison.
FINDINGS:  The cervicomedullary junction is within normal limits.  There is no
abnormal signal in or enhancement of the cervical spinal cord.  There is no
evidence of meningeal enhancement or cervical spinal cord compression.  The
marrow signal of the cervical vertebra is diffusely increased on the STIR
images.  There is also mild diffuse enhancement of the marrow cavities of the

stable-appearing tiny noncalcified pulmonary nodule within the lingula.  There
are no pleural effusions.  The liver
glands
note_date: and right kidney are grossly normal.  Two hypodense exophytic lesions

person_id: arising from the left kidney are unchanged.  The stomach and visualized loops
of small and large bowel are unremarkable.  No pathologically enlarged
mesenteric or retroperitoneal lymph nodes are identified.  Note is made of
atherosclerotic changes of the abdominal aorta
branches are patent.  There is no free fluid within the abdomen.
CT OF THE PELVIS WITH IV CONTRAST:  The urinary bladder
seminal vesicles
note_time: and pelvic loops of bowel appear grossly

person_id: normal.  A small amount of free pelvic fluid is present.
BONE WINDOWS:  No suspicious lytic or blastic lesions are identified.
IMPRESSION:
1)  Stable appearance of tiny noncalcified lingular nodule.
2)  Stable appearance of two hypodense exophytic lesions arising from the left
kidney.  These are incompletely characterized in this study but most likely
represent cysts.
3) No mesenteric or retroperitoneal lymphadenopathy identified.

emboli.

note_date: an 0.035 [**Doctor Last Name 471**] wire was placed through the sheath and advanced

person_id: under fluoroscopy until its tip was in the inferior vena cava. The
micropuncture sheath was exchanged for a 6 French sheath. The focal stenosis
in the cephalic vein was dilated using a 6 mm X 4 cm balloon. Resolution of
the narrowing was shown on a follow-up venogram.
The sheath was removed and a 18 mm X 4 cm balloon was placed over the wire
into the stenotic SVC and dilated repeatedly under fluoroscopy up to 5
atmospheres. Follow up venograms through the sidearm of the sheath showed
significant improvement of the diameter of the SVC. Repeat pressure
measurements through a 4 French multiside hole straight catheter showed
complete resolution of pressure gradient across the superior vena cava.
The catheter and sheath were then removed and local hemostasis was achieved by
manual compression. The patient tolerated the procedure well with no
complications.

Resp: Looking good on PSV 5 with 5cm peep. Good sats 95%-98% most of the night. The plan is to extubated him today. He is being suctioned for thick pale yellow to white secretions.

GU: UO is excellent via the foley.
Skin: Buttocks/coccyx is red/broken and excoriated. Pt turned and positioned. Dressings done to both his feet.
Social: Family are all in aggreement that they want him to be extubated and not to be reintubated. Order written. Pt is DNR/DNI. No pressors. Comfort will be main goal if he fails.

HISTORY: 63 year old male with end stage renal disease on dialysis through
left arm brachiocephalic arteriovenous (AV) fistula
significant swelling of left face and both arms with left side being worse.
RADIOLOGISTS: Drs. [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) 603**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 470**] and [**Name5 (PTitle) 291**] [**Doctor Last Name 292**] d'Othee
radiologist Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 292**] [**Name (STitle) 293**] being present for the entire procedure. Dr.
[**Last Name (STitle) 212**] reviewed the exam.
PROCEDURE AND FINDINGS: The risks and benefits were explained to the patient
and consent was obtained. The patient was placed supine on the angiographic
table and the right arm was prepped and draped in sterile fashion. Local
anesthesia using 1% Lidocaine was applied to the puncture site. Under
sonographic guidance
note_date: the left cephalic vein near the arteriovenous fistula

person_id: was accessed using a 21 gauge needle and an 0.018 wire was placed into the
vein toward the venous side. The needle was exchanged for a micropuncture
sheath which was connected to the power injector.
AV fistulogram was performed along the course of the cephalic vein to the
level of the right atrium. The venograms demonstrated a focal stenosis in the
dilated cephalic vein at the level of the mid arm and also confirmed the
known
note_date: severe stenosis of the superior vena cava (SVC). There is a left

person_id: internal jugular dialysis catheter with its tip in the SVC. This might be
related to the development of the stenosis. No intrathoracic collateral is
seen; there is
note_time: collateral filling from the left mid-arm towards the

person_id: axilla and then left lateral thoracic wall caudally.
Pressure measurements were performed through a 5-French straight catheter.
They demonstrated mean pressures of 13 mmHg in the right atrium and 31 mmHg in
the left brachiocephalic vein (i.e.
A pressure cuff was insufflated over the upper arm and a venogram was
repeated. It revealed patency of the arteriovenous anastomosis and the
brachial artery proximally and distally to the anastomosis with no significant
stenosis.
(Over)
AV FISTULOGRAM SCH                                              Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 13293**]
Reason: functioning AVF
Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 150
FINAL REPORT
(Cont)
Thereafter
note_date: an 0.035 [**Doctor Last Name 471**] wire was placed through the sheath and advanced

person_id: under fluoroscopy until its tip was in the inferior vena cava. The
micropuncture sheath was exchanged for a 6 French sheath. The focal stenosis
in the cephalic vein was dilated using a 6 mm X 4 cm balloon. Resolution of
the narrowing was shown on a follow-up venogram.
The sheath was removed and a 18 mm X 4 cm balloon was placed over the wire
into the stenotic SVC and dilated repeatedly under fluoroscopy up to 5
atmospheres. Follow up venograms through the sidearm of the sheath showed
significant improvement of the diameter of the SVC. Repeat pressure
measurements through a 4 French multiside hole straight catheter showed
complete resolution of pressure gradient across the superior vena cava.
The catheter and sheath were then removed and local hemostasis was achieved by
manual compression. The patient tolerated the procedure well with no
complications.
MEDICATIONS: For conscious sedation
note_date: a total of 75 micrograms of Fentanyl was

person_id: given in small divided intravenous doses under continuous hemodynamic
monitoring. Total of 165 ml IV Optiray 320 dilated by half.
IMPRESSION:
1.  Major
note_date: symptomatic stenosis of the superior vena cava. Low-pressure

person_id: balloon venoplasty (18 mm) resulted in highly satisfactory immediate
angiographic and manometric results.
2.  Focal stenosis in the left cephalic vein at the mid-arm level. This was
dilated to 6 mm in diameter with no immediate complication.

Reason: CT abdomen/pelvis with PO & IV contrast. Evaluate for intraa

CT abdomen/pelvis with PO & IV contrast. Evaluate for intraabdominal abscess.
No contraindications for IV contrast
FINAL REPORT
INDICATION:  64-year-old woman with necrotizing pancreatitis.  Please evaluate
for intra-abdominal pathology.
Comparison is made to the prior study performed on [**3430-8-12**].
TECHNIQUE:  Axial MDCT images were obtained from lung bases to pubic symphysis
after administration of 130 cc of Optiray intravenously.  Oral contrast was
also used.  Sagittal and coronal reformatted images were acquired.
CT OF THE ABDOMEN WITH IV CONTRAST:
The visualized portion of the lung bases demonstrates stable appearnce of
multiple foci of loculated effusion and atelectasis of the base of left lung.
Small amount of right pleural effusion is noted.  The visualized portion of
the right lung is unremarkable.  The end of CV line is noted within the distal
SVC.  The visualized portion of the aortic stent is unchanged. Multiple
surgical clips are noted near the diaphragmatic crura.
Peripancreatic inflammation is stable. Localized areas of fluid collection
surrounding the pancreas (anterior border of the pancreatic head
pancreatic tail and inferior to the pancreatic head) are unchanged. A drainage
tube starting the pancreatic bed and ending in the right upper quadrant area
is also noted.
Th liver contains multiple small hypodense lesions which are too small to
characterize. The gallbladder contains a large gallstone with no evidence of
cholecystitis. The intra and extrahepatic bile ducts are normal. The spleen
adrenal glands
note_date: small bowel and large bowel loops appear unremarkable. Patient

person_id: is status post PEG tube placement.  Both kidneys contains multiple hypodense
lesions
note_date: some of which most likely represents cysts

person_id: lesions do not have the appearance of a simple cyst.
The large ventral defect of the anterior abdominal wall is unchanged. The
small amount of gas tracking from the wound into the peritoneal space is
unchanged. Foci of soft tissue density within the anterior abdominal fat are
likely related to the injection sites.  No pathologically enlarged
retroperitoneal or mesenteric nodes are noted.  No free air or fluid is noted
within the abdomen and pelvis.
CT OF THE PELVIS WITH IV CONTRAST:  The rectum

now +thrill but difficulty accessing.  [**Hospital Unit Name 3017**] recommends AV graft dye study.
REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
Evaluate patency
FINAL REPORT
HISTORY:  87-year-old man with hemodialysis graft in the right upper extremity
with no thrill
RADIOLOGISTS:  Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 3018**] and Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 1883**]
and supervising the entire procedure.
FINDINGS/TECHNIQUE:  The patient was placed supine on the angiographic table
after appropriate consent was obtained.  The right arm was prepped and draped
in sterile fashion.  The graft was accessed with a 21-gauge needle after 1%
lidocaine was used for local anesthesia.  The 0.018 guidewire was advanced
toward the central venous circulation and the needle was exchanged for a 4.5-
French introducer sheath.  Venogram performed with and without placement of a
tourniquet over the axillary vein demonstrated tight venous stenosis
immediately adjacent to the anastomosis between the graft and the brachial
vein.  Based on the diagnostic findings
note_date: it was decided that the patient was a

person_id: good candidate for and would benefit from angioplasty.  0.035 [**Last Name (un) 1477**] wire was
placed into the sheath and the sheath was exchanged for a 5- French
angiographic sheath. 6 mm
sequential balloon dilatation of the venous stenosis. A followup venogram
demonstrated substantial improvement in the luminal diameter of the brachial
veins adjacent to the graft-to-vein anastomosis.
COMPLICATIONS:  No immediate complications.
IMPRESSION:  Angiogram of the AV graft in the right arm demonstrated tight
stenosis of the brachial vein adjacent to the graft-to-vein anastomosis.
Angioplasty with 6 mm and 8 mm none-cutting balloons was performed with good
results.
(Over)

hypotension and left flank pain and bruising.
TECHNIQUE: Contiguous axial images were obtained from the lung bases through
the symphysis pubis prior to and following the administration of 150 cc of
Optiray. Nonionic contrast was used due to patient allergy history.
COMPARISON: None available.
CT OF THE ABDOMEN WITHOUT AND WITH IV CONTRAST: The visualized lung bases
demonstrate small left pleural effusion with associated atelectatic changes.
Patient has undergone cholecystectomy. The liver
appear grossly normal. There is splenomegaly
of 16.8 cm. The spleen is diffusely heterogeneous
lesions. However
note_date: evaluation is limited do to the early timing of the contrast

person_id: bolus. There is a 5.6 x 5.7 cm bilobed right renal cyst. Both kidneys are
otherwise unremarkable. Stomach and proximal loops of small and large bowel
are unremarkable. There are a few prominent but nonpathologically enlarged
left paraaortic and mesenteric lymph nodes. The aorta and its major branches
are widely patent. There is no free fluid or air within the abdomen.
CT OF THE PELVIS WITHOUT AND WITH IV CONTRAST: The urinary bladder is
distended but is otherwise unremarkable. Patient appears to have undergone
hysterectomy. Pelvic loops of bowel are grossly within normal limits. There is
no free fluid.
BONE WINDOWS: Degenerative changes of the mid thoracic spine are noted. No
suspicious lytic or blastic lesions are identified.
IMPRESSION:
1. No evidence of intra or retroperitoneal hemorrhage.
2. Splenomeglay as above with increased heterogeneity and possible focal
splenic lesions. Given the timing of the contrast [**Last Name (LF) 12614**]
recommended for further evaluation.
3. Small left pleural effusion and associated atelectatic changes.

infarction

clear.

degenerative in origin.

1999.  There are areas of chronic microvascular ischemia/infarction in both

exam is slightly limited as IV contrast was administered several hours prior
to the performance of this study.

Reason: SEPSIS/?ABSCESS

no pathologic pelvic or inguinal lymphadenopathy seen.

Brief Hospital Course:
28 y/o male with no known PMH at the time found down s/p cardiac
arrest. PEA then VT then VF. Successful resuscitation with 2
shocks. The patient suffered anoxic brain injury s/p cardiac
arrest.
1. s/p cardiac arrest
The patient was initially found down in [**Location (un) 1194**]. Please
see above HPI for further details. After arriving at [**Hospital1 19**] ED
he was ruled out for any traumatic injury. He was then
transferred to the CCU for further evaluation and management
after his cardiac arrest. Due to his recent VF arrest
hypothermia protocol was initiated and the patient was cooled
for 18 hours. GCS before protocol was initiated was 3. The
patient met all inclusion criteria and he had none of the
exclusion criteria. Following the cooling protocol
re-warmed. Upon initial arrival to the CCU
for any evidence of arrhythmia or abnormality that would explain
his cardiac arrest. Echocardiogram was performed soon after the
patient arrived in the CCU which was negative for any structural
abnormality of the heart. See full echo report above for
details. Initial tox screen was positive for opiates and benzos.
The leading diagnosis after cardiac causes were ruled out were
possible substance abuse causing respiratory suppression then
hypoxia which may have induced the cardiac arrest. Since the
patient was never awake from presentation
impossible. After talking with his family
he had a history of substance abuse and was most likely using
heroin and/or benzos prior to being found down. The exact
etiology of what caused the patient's cardiac arrest remained
uncertain. Due to the patient's anoxic brain injury and after
consulting neurology
note_date: the family decided to withdraw support on

person_id: [**2993-7-31**] and the patient expired soon afterwards.
2. Anoxic brain injury
After the patient was transferred to the CCU
consulted so they could perform an exam while patient was off
sedation prior to initiating cooling protocol. Upon arrival to
the CCU
note_date: the patient was having myoclonic jerking which was more

person_id: consistent with anoxic brain injury than seizure activity.
Neurology recommended EEG and then continued EEG monitoring. On
initial exam
note_date: the patient did have a gag reflex and corneal

person_id: reflexes. However
reflexes were absent
note_date: even off sedation for 48 hours. He was

person_id: monitored continuously with EEG which showed no signs of
activity. He was maintained initially on Dilantin to control any
seizures secondary to anoxic brain injury and that was
eventually discontinued. Organ bank saw the patient and
determined that he was not a suitable candidate for organ
donation. During the last two days of the patient's
hospitalization
note_date: he began to show evidence of multi-organ

person_id: failure and required pressor support to maintain his BP. After
several discussions with the family
was communicated that the patient would never return to normal
functioning. The family decided in complete agreement to
withdraw support on [**2993-7-31**] and the patient passed away soon
after the night of the 16th at 21:15. The family declined
autopsy.

FINAL REPORT
PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Left vertebral artery origin stenosis.
POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Same status post stent angioplasty of the left
vertebral artery origin.
ANESTHESIA: General endotracheal anesthesia.
INDICATION FOR PROCEDURE: Mr. [**Known patient lastname 7289**] is a 69-year-old man who was found to
have a left vertebral artery critical stenosis as well as bilateral carotid
artery disease. He is status post carotid endarterectomy and is now slated to
undergo treatment of his vertebral origin stenosis.
CONSENT: The patient and his family was given a full and complete explanation
of the procedure. Specifically
alternatives to the procedure were explained in detail. In addition
possible complications
note_date: such as the risk of bleeding

person_id: neurological deficit or deterioration
complications including the risk of coma and even death
patient and his family understood and wished to proceed with the operation.
PROCEDURE IN DETAIL: The patient was brought into the Endovascular Suite and
placed on the table in supine position. The left groin area was prepped and
draped in the usual sterile fashion. A 19-gauge single-wall needle was then
used to puncture the left common femoral artery
note_date: and upon the return of brisk

person_id: arterial blood
note_date: a 7 French vascular sheath was inserted over a guidewire and

person_id: kept on a heparinized saline drip. Next
note_date: a diagnostic catheter was used to

person_id: selectively catheterize the following vessels: left subclavian artery
vertebral artery. After obtaining access and placement of a guidecatheter into
the left vertebral artery an angiogrphic run was performed. The patient was
administered heparinization to achieve an activated clotting time of 250
seconds. He was then pretreated with plavix and aspirin. At this point a
microwire was used to cross the critical stenosis and subsequently a 2 mm x 9
mm Maverick over-the-wire balloon was used to perform angioplasty of the
origin of the left vertebral artery. The balloon was then withdrawn and an AVE
(Over)
CAROT/CEREB [**Hospital1 59**]                                                  Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 7293**]
Reason: VERT STENOSIS
Admitting Diagnosis: CVA
Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 150
FINAL REPORT
(Cont)
S670 4 mm x 9 mm was used to perform angioplasty at the origin of the left
vertebral artery. The balloon was then removed and angiographic run was
performed through the left subclavian artery with the wire crossing the left
vertebral artery. This showed no evidence of dissection and a good
angiographic result with complete resolution of the stenosis at the left
vertebral artery origin. Small portion of the stent is seen to extend into the
left subclavian artery. However this does not represent any consequence in
terms of flow limitation and is unavoidable in order to perform adequate
angioplasty of the stenotic segment. At this point the microwire was removed
from the left vertebral artery and an angiographic run was performed of the
left subclavian artery which showed excellent improvement in the stenosis in
the antegrade flow. Angiographic run of the intracranial portion of the left
vertebral artery showed a patent basilar artery and patent bilateral posterior
cerebral and bilateral superior cerebellar artery in the right-sided ICA
vessel with a left-sided ICA-PICA vessel. There is a little bit of retrograde
reflux into the right vertebral artery which was previously documented to be
occluded proximally. At this point the guidecatheter was withdrawn from the
patient and an angiographic run was performed of the iliac artery which
appears to be heavily calcified and hypotrophied and accordingly a manual
compression was used later to remove the sheath. Patient did well
neurologically and was transferred to intensive care unit in stable condition.
IMPRESSION: Critical left vertebral artery origin stenosis treated using
primary angioplasty followed by stent angioplasty with significant improvement
in left vertebral artery flow.

FINAL REPORT
PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Left vertebral artery origin stenosis.
POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Same status post stent angioplasty of the left
vertebral artery origin.
ANESTHESIA: General endotracheal anesthesia.
INDICATION FOR PROCEDURE: Mr. [**Known patient lastname 7289**] is a 69-year-old man who was found to
have a left vertebral artery critical stenosis as well as bilateral carotid
artery disease. He is status post carotid endarterectomy and is now slated to
undergo treatment of his vertebral origin stenosis.
CONSENT: The patient and his family was given a full and complete explanation
of the procedure. Specifically
alternatives to the procedure were explained in detail. In addition
possible complications
note_date: such as the risk of bleeding

person_id: neurological deficit or deterioration
complications including the risk of coma and even death
patient and his family understood and wished to proceed with the operation.
PROCEDURE IN DETAIL: The patient was brought into the Endovascular Suite and
placed on the table in supine position. The left groin area was prepped and
draped in the usual sterile fashion. A 19-gauge single-wall needle was then
used to puncture the left common femoral artery
note_date: and upon the return of brisk

person_id: arterial blood
note_date: a 7 French vascular sheath was inserted over a guidewire and

person_id: kept on a heparinized saline drip. Next
note_date: a diagnostic catheter was used to

person_id: selectively catheterize the following vessels: left subclavian artery
vertebral artery. After obtaining access and placement of a guidecatheter into
the left vertebral artery an angiogrphic run was performed. The patient was
administered heparinization to achieve an activated clotting time of 250
seconds. He was then pretreated with plavix and aspirin. At this point a
microwire was used to cross the critical stenosis and subsequently a 2 mm x 9
mm Maverick over-the-wire balloon was used to perform angioplasty of the
origin of the left vertebral artery. The balloon was then withdrawn and an AVE
(Over)
CAROT/CEREB [**Hospital1 59**]                                                  Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 7293**]
Reason: VERT STENOSIS
Admitting Diagnosis: CVA
Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 150
FINAL REPORT
(Cont)
S670 4 mm x 9 mm was used to perform angioplasty at the origin of the left
vertebral artery. The balloon was then removed and angiographic run was
performed through the left subclavian artery with the wire crossing the left
vertebral artery. This showed no evidence of dissection and a good
angiographic result with complete resolution of the stenosis at the left
vertebral artery origin. Small portion of the stent is seen to extend into the
left subclavian artery. However this does not represent any consequence in
terms of flow limitation and is unavoidable in order to perform adequate
angioplasty of the stenotic segment. At this point the microwire was removed
from the left vertebral artery and an angiographic run was performed of the
left subclavian artery which showed excellent improvement in the stenosis in
the antegrade flow. Angiographic run of the intracranial portion of the left
vertebral artery showed a patent basilar artery and patent bilateral posterior
cerebral and bilateral superior cerebellar artery in the right-sided ICA
vessel with a left-sided ICA-PICA vessel. There is a little bit of retrograde
reflux into the right vertebral artery which was previously documented to be
occluded proximally. At this point the guidecatheter was withdrawn from the
patient and an angiographic run was performed of the iliac artery which
appears to be heavily calcified and hypotrophied and accordingly a manual
compression was used later to remove the sheath. Patient did well
neurologically and was transferred to intensive care unit in stable condition.
IMPRESSION: Critical left vertebral artery origin stenosis treated using
primary angioplasty followed by stent angioplasty with significant improvement
in left vertebral artery flow.

CAROT/CEREB [**Hospital1 59**]                                                  Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 7293**]
Reason: VERT STENOSIS
Admitting Diagnosis: CVA
Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 150
FINAL REPORT
(Cont)
S670 4 mm x 9 mm was used to perform angioplasty at the origin of the left
vertebral artery. The balloon was then removed and angiographic run was
performed through the left subclavian artery with the wire crossing the left
vertebral artery. This showed no evidence of dissection and a good
angiographic result with complete resolution of the stenosis at the left
vertebral artery origin. Small portion of the stent is seen to extend into the
left subclavian artery. However this does not represent any consequence in
terms of flow limitation and is unavoidable in order to perform adequate
angioplasty of the stenotic segment. At this point the microwire was removed
from the left vertebral artery and an angiographic run was performed of the
left subclavian artery which showed excellent improvement in the stenosis in
the antegrade flow. Angiographic run of the intracranial portion of the left
vertebral artery showed a patent basilar artery and patent bilateral posterior
cerebral and bilateral superior cerebellar artery in the right-sided ICA
vessel with a left-sided ICA-PICA vessel. There is a little bit of retrograde
reflux into the right vertebral artery which was previously documented to be
occluded proximally. At this point the guidecatheter was withdrawn from the
patient and an angiographic run was performed of the iliac artery which
appears to be heavily calcified and hypotrophied and accordingly a manual
compression was used later to remove the sheath. Patient did well
neurologically and was transferred to intensive care unit in stable condition.
IMPRESSION: Critical left vertebral artery origin stenosis treated using
primary angioplasty followed by stent angioplasty with significant improvement
in left vertebral artery flow.

approximately 50%.  Note is made of hypokinesis along the inferior wall.
No prior studies are available for comparison.

note_date: primarily fixed perfusion defect along the inferior

person_id: wall.  There is associated hypokinesis of the inferior wall.  Enlarged right
ventricle.  2) Ejection fraction of 50%. /nkg

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Left vertebral artery origin stenosis.
POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Same status post stent angioplasty of the left
vertebral artery origin.
ANESTHESIA: General endotracheal anesthesia.
INDICATION FOR PROCEDURE: Mr. [**Known patient lastname 7289**] is a 69-year-old man who was found to
have a left vertebral artery critical stenosis as well as bilateral carotid
artery disease. He is status post carotid endarterectomy and is now slated to
undergo treatment of his vertebral origin stenosis.
CONSENT: The patient and his family was given a full and complete explanation
of the procedure. Specifically
alternatives to the procedure were explained in detail. In addition
possible complications
note_date: such as the risk of bleeding

person_id: neurological deficit or deterioration
complications including the risk of coma and even death
patient and his family understood and wished to proceed with the operation.
PROCEDURE IN DETAIL: The patient was brought into the Endovascular Suite and
placed on the table in supine position. The left groin area was prepped and
draped in the usual sterile fashion. A 19-gauge single-wall needle was then
used to puncture the left common femoral artery
note_date: and upon the return of brisk

person_id: arterial blood
note_date: a 7 French vascular sheath was inserted over a guidewire and

person_id: kept on a heparinized saline drip. Next
note_date: a diagnostic catheter was used to

person_id: selectively catheterize the following vessels: left subclavian artery
vertebral artery. After obtaining access and placement of a guidecatheter into
the left vertebral artery an angiogrphic run was performed. The patient was
administered heparinization to achieve an activated clotting time of 250
seconds. He was then pretreated with plavix and aspirin. At this point a
microwire was used to cross the critical stenosis and subsequently a 2 mm x 9
mm Maverick over-the-wire balloon was used to perform angioplasty of the
origin of the left vertebral artery. The balloon was then withdrawn and an AVE
(Over)
CAROT/CEREB [**Hospital1 59**]                                                  Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 7293**]
Reason: VERT STENOSIS
Admitting Diagnosis: CVA
Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 150
FINAL REPORT
(Cont)
S670 4 mm x 9 mm was used to perform angioplasty at the origin of the left
vertebral artery. The balloon was then removed and angiographic run was
performed through the left subclavian artery with the wire crossing the left
vertebral artery. This showed no evidence of dissection and a good
angiographic result with complete resolution of the stenosis at the left
vertebral artery origin. Small portion of the stent is seen to extend into the
left subclavian artery. However this does not represent any consequence in
terms of flow limitation and is unavoidable in order to perform adequate
angioplasty of the stenotic segment. At this point the microwire was removed
from the left vertebral artery and an angiographic run was performed of the
left subclavian artery which showed excellent improvement in the stenosis in
the antegrade flow. Angiographic run of the intracranial portion of the left
vertebral artery showed a patent basilar artery and patent bilateral posterior
cerebral and bilateral superior cerebellar artery in the right-sided ICA
vessel with a left-sided ICA-PICA vessel. There is a little bit of retrograde
reflux into the right vertebral artery which was previously documented to be
occluded proximally. At this point the guidecatheter was withdrawn from the
patient and an angiographic run was performed of the iliac artery which
appears to be heavily calcified and hypotrophied and accordingly a manual
compression was used later to remove the sheath. Patient did well
neurologically and was transferred to intensive care unit in stable condition.
IMPRESSION: Critical left vertebral artery origin stenosis treated using
primary angioplasty followed by stent angioplasty with significant improvement
in left vertebral artery flow.

HISTORY:  62 year-old woman with end stage renal disease and right IJ
tunnedled dialysis catheter.  CT scan showed thrombus around the catheter in
the SVC.
PROCEDURE AND FINDINGS:  The procedure was performed by Drs. [**Last Name (STitle) 1130**]
who was present and supervising.  Informed consent was obtained.  The
patient's right upper arm was prepped and draped in standard sterile fashion.
After infusion of 1% Lidocaine
note_date: the right brachial vein accessed under

person_id: ultrasonographic guidance with a 21-gauge needle.  Hardcopy ultrasound images
were obtained before and after access.  An 018 wire was advanced into the
brachiocephalic vein and the puncture needle was exchanged for a 4-French
catheter.  Venogram was performed which demonstrated occlusion of the superior
vena cava with extensive filling of collaterals.  The 4-French catheter was
then exchanged over a wire for a 5-French sheath
continuous flush.  Using a glidewire and C2-Cobra catheter
was obtained across the SVC occlusion.  The Cobra catheter was then exchanged
for a 10 cm TPA infusion catheter.  The catheter was positioned across the
area of SVC occlusion.  Contrast was injected demonstrating filling defects
within the SVC consistent with thrombus.  5 mm of TPA were then bolused
through the infusion catheter.  Following the bolus
infusion of TPA was started.  200 units per hour of Heparin were infused
through the sheath.  The sheath and catheter were then secured with suture
steri-strips
note_date: and tegaderms.  The patient tolerated the procedure well and

person_id: there are no immediate postprocedure complications.
IMPRESSION:  1. Complete occlusion of the SVC with thrombus.
2.  Placement of TPA infusion catheter across the SVC occlusion.  5 mg bolus
of TPA administered and 0.5 mg per hour infusion commenced.
3.  The patient should retrun interventional radiology the following morning
for follow-up venogram.
(Over)

RADIOLOGISTS: Dr. [**First Name (STitle) 132**] [**Name (STitle) 107**] d'Othee and Dr. [**First Name (STitle) 320**] [**Name (STitle) 321**]. Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 107**]

note_time: was present for the entire procedure.

person_id: TECHNIQUE AND FINDINGS: Informed consent was obtained prior to the procedure.
The patient was placed supine on the angiography table and MAC anesthesia was
started by the Anesthesiology Team. Focused ultrasonic examination of the
abdomen showed a mild to moderate amount of fluid around the liver. Therefore
no paracentesis was attempted.
The right supraclavicular area and right side of the neck were sterilely
draped and prepped as usually. Using real-time ultrasound guidance
internal jugular vein was accessed with a 21 gauge needle after subcutaneous
infiltration of lidocaine 1% for local anesthesia. An 0.018 guidewire was
advanced under fluoroscopic guidance up to the right atrium and the needle was
exchanged for a 4.5 French micropuncture sheath. An 0.035 standard guidewire
was advanced through the sheath into inferior vena cava (IVC) and the
percutaneous access tract was dilated over the wire until it accomodated a
long
note_time: the sidearm of which was connected to continuous

person_id: irrigation with normal saline.
The right hepatic vein was accessed with a Cobra C2 Glidecatheter and an 0.035
glidewire. After exchange for an 0.035 SuperStiff Amplatz wire
sheath was advanced under fluoroscopy into the right hepatic vein over the
wire and its dilator. A 5 French balloon occlusion catheter was then
positioned in the right hepatic vein and inflated in a wedge position. A wedge
hepatic venogram was obtained by using carbon dioxide (CO2) as contrast [**Doctor Last Name 322**].
This was done in both posterior anterior and lateral projections. These two
wedge hepatic venograms showed opacification of the peripheral portion of the
right hepatic vein
note_date: parenchymography in the corresponding right hepatic

person_id: territory
note_date: and retrograde opacification of the right and left branches of the

person_id: portal vein and their branches
note_date: as well as opacification of the main trunk of

person_id: the portal vein. It also allowed to precise the relationship between the right
hepatic vein and the right branch of the portal vein.
(Over)

of the right intrahepatic duct was done
intrahepatic bile ducts as well as the common hepatic duct. Using this
landmark
note_date: the right branch of the portal vein was then easily punctured with

person_id: the needle

person_id: the portal vein and the splenic vein.
The needle was removed over the wire and exchanged for a 5 French straight
multi-sidehole catheter through which iodinated contrast portogram was
performed. This portogram in the PA projection showed opacification of the
main portal vein and its intrahepatic branches
inferior mesenteric veins. No gastric varices were seen.
The catheter was then exchanged over a wire for a 10 x 40 mm balloon

again
note_date: and an additional postero-anterior portogram was obtained and showed

note_date: and provided landmarks for future stent placement.

person_id: A 10 x 68 mm Wallstent was then positioned under fluoroscopy between the

UNDERLYING MEDICAL CONDITION:
49 year old woman with end stage liver disease and renal failure.
REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
{Please placed a LEFT IJ TEMPORARY DIALYSIS CATHETER AT BEDSIDE.
FINAL REPORT
INDICATION: End stage liver disease and renal failure.
PROCEDURE/FINDINGS: The procedure was performed by Drs. [**Last Name (STitle) 351**] and [**Name5 (PTitle) 126**]
with Dr. [**First Name (STitle) 126**]
note_date: the attending radiologist being present and supervising

person_id: throughout. After discussion of the risks and benefits with the patient's
health care proxy
note_date: telephone consent was obtained. Prior to the procedure the

person_id: patient received two units of platelets
note_date: four units of FFP and cryoprecipitate

person_id: given the patient's coagulopathy.  The left neck was prepped and draped in the
standard sterile fashion.  Local anesthesia was achieved with subcutaneous
injection of approximately 5 cc of 1% lidocaine. The left internal jugular
vein was found to be patent and compressible by ultrasound. The left internal
jugular vein was then accessed using a 21 gauge needle under ultrasonographic
guidance. A 0.018 guide wire was passed into the internal jugular vein and
into the superior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance using a portable C-
arm
note_date: at the patient's bedside.  Following a skin [**Doctor Last Name 352**] with a scalpel blade

person_id: the puncture needle was then exchanged for a 4 French catheter sheath with
inner dilator. The guide wire and inner sheath were then exchanged for a 0.035
guide wire which was then advanced into the inferior vena cava under
fluoroscopic guidance.  The track was sequentially dilated up to a 14 French
dilator.  A 14.5 French sheath was then advanced over the wire.  The wire and
inner dilator were then exchanged for the hemodialysis catheter.  The sheath
was then removed. The tip of the catheter was demonstrated to be within the
right atrium under fluoroscopy.  The line was flushed and heplocked. The
catheter was then secured with 0-silk sutures.  The exit site was covered with
Gelfoam and a pressure dressing.  The patient tolerated the procedure well
with no immediate post procedural complications.
IMPRESSION: Successful placement of a 14.5 French dual-lumen temporary
dialysis catheter via the left internal jugular vein with the tip at the
cavoatrial junction  ready for use.
(Over)

jugular vein was then accessed using a 21 gauge needle under ultrasonographic
guidance. A 0.018 guide wire was passed into the internal jugular vein and
into the superior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance using a portable C-
arm
note_date: at the patient's bedside.  Following a skin [**Doctor Last Name 352**] with a scalpel blade

person_id: the puncture needle was then exchanged for a 4 French catheter sheath with
inner dilator. The guide wire and inner sheath were then exchanged for a 0.035
guide wire which was then advanced into the inferior vena cava under
fluoroscopic guidance.  The track was sequentially dilated up to a 14 French
dilator.  A 14.5 French sheath was then advanced over the wire.  The wire and
inner dilator were then exchanged for the hemodialysis catheter.  The sheath
was then removed. The tip of the catheter was demonstrated to be within the
right atrium under fluoroscopy.  The line was flushed and heplocked. The
catheter was then secured with 0-silk sutures.  The exit site was covered with
Gelfoam and a pressure dressing.  The patient tolerated the procedure well
with no immediate post procedural complications.
IMPRESSION: Successful placement of a 14.5 French dual-lumen temporary
dialysis catheter via the left internal jugular vein with the tip at the
cavoatrial junction  ready for use.

encountered.  The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate

Brief Hospital Course:
74 M with fever and hypotension intubated electively for airway
protection.
# Hypotension:
He was hypotensive in the emergency department which was of
unclear etiology.  This was thought most likely to be due to
hypovolemia due to dehydration as his blood pressure normalized
with IV fluids.  By the end of his hospitalization he had
actually started to become hypertensive and was started on
lisinopril 10 mg daily.  His HCTZ was not restarted as it was
thought this may have been contributing to his hyponatremia.
Fever:
This was of unclear etiology and was attributed to a likely
viral syndrome.  He had no localizing signs or symptoms of
infection.  A test for influenza was negative as was a urine
culture.  Blood cultures were pending at discharge.  He was
initially treated with broad spectrum antibiotics including
vancomycin
data was negative he was switched to po levofloxacin and he was
discharged to complete a seven day course.
# Resp Failure:
He was intubated in the ED for airway protection but he was
successfully extubated shortly after arriving to the MICU and
maintained a normal O2 saturation throughout the rest of his
hospital course.
# Hyponatremia:
On admission he was initially hyponatremic with a sodium of 129.
This was thought to be due to a combination of hypovolemia from
dehydration as well as HCTX effect.  With hydration and stopping
his HCTZ his sodium normalized and at discharge it was 134.
# Cervical radiculopathy:
He has a history of this and was last seen in neurology clinic
in [**2649**].  He intermittently complained of neck pain during his
admission and was set up with a follow-up appointment in
neurology with Dr. [**First Name (STitle) 4198**] on [**3-24**] at 3:00.
# Lower back pain:
He has a history of chronic lower back pain and spinal stenosis
and has been followed in the pain management center.  He was
kept on his gabapentin and has a follow-up appointment with the
pain clinic.
# Urinary hesitancy:
This is also a chronic issue for him and he was started on
tamsulosin during his hospitalization with some effect.  He has
a follow-up appointment in the urology clinic.
# Focal mesenteric thickening on CT scan:
His abdominal exam was benign and he did not complain of
abdominal pain.  The general surgery service was consulted and
did not recommend any intervention.
# Dispo:
He was discharged to home with plans for home physical therapy
as he had previously had.  He was also set up for appointments
with his PCP
